awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EARS: Spectrum and Energy Efficient Radio Resource Access in Wireless Networks with Densely Deployed Underlay Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless traffic volume is expected to expand tremendously in the next few years. Sustaining this growing trend will require high spectrum efficiency. In the meantime, energy efficiency has become another essential requirement for future wireless networks. Furthermore, as video content delivery over wireless networks is expected to escalate fast, how to support these energy and bandwidth consuming video applications with high Quality of Experience is becoming a very challenging issue in future wireless networks. Inspired by recent advances in wireless technologies and challenges, the proposed research aims to develop Quality of Experience aware spectrum efficient and energy efficient radio resource access schemes in next generation wireless networks with densely deployed underlay devices. The proposed research project and activities have significant potentials to enhancing access to the radio spectrum and wireless services. The project will investigate a new wireless network paradigm to meet the ever increasing new devices, wireless traffic demand, and to address the needs on global environmental protection. The proposed research will also improve Quality of Experience for wireless videos, which will be the dominant wireless traffic in the coming years. 

This project will identify unique technical challenges in wireless networks with densely deployed underlay devices and explore new solutions to research problems, including distributed opportunistic spectrum access schemes to achieve high spectrum efficiency, optimum energy efficiency schemes and energy and spectrum efficiency tradeoffs, and Quality of Experience aware spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency in wireless networks with densely deployed underlay devices. Theoretical analysis and performance evaluation for novel radio spectrum access schemes in wireless networks with densely deployed underlay devices will be obtained. Simulation and performance evaluation tools will be developed and shared with the broader scientific research and engineering community. The proposed research will significantly advance the understanding in the field of radio spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency as well as Quality of Experience for video applications for emerging wireless networks with densely deployed underlay devices, which are expected to play a key role in the modem society to meet the future wireless capacity explosion and energy consumption escalation. The project will give both undergraduate and graduate students direct simulation modeling experience as well as research opportunities in designing and developing new wireless technologies. With an emphasis on integrating research and education, curriculum development and improvement, and diversity and outreach, PIs are committed on the continuous achievement on educating and training students, especially female students and students from under-represented groups, and prepare them for the workforces of future wireless telecommunications industry and society.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated spectrum efficient and energy efficient radio resource access schemes with Quality of Experience (QoE) assurance for video applications in the next generation wireless network with densely deployed underlay devices (WN-DDUD). The proposed research aims at investigating novel radio resource access schemes that can balance and optimize spectrum efficiency (SE), energy efficiency (EE) and QoE in a WN-DDUD that supports video applications. The approaches include identifying unique technical challenges in a WN-DDUD and exploring new solutions to research problems, such as distributed opportunistic spectrum access schemes to achieve high spectrum efficiency, optimum energy efficiency schemes and energy and spectrum efficiency tradeoffs, and QoE-aware spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency in a WN-DDUD. Theoretical analysis and performance evaluation for novel radio spectrum access schemes in a WN-DDUD have been obtained.

The research activities have resulted significant potentials to enhancing access to the radio spectrum and wireless services. The project investigated a new wireless network paradigm to meet the ever increasing new devices, wireless traffic demand, and to address the needs on global environmental protection. The research also improved QoE for wireless videos, which will be the dominant wireless traffic in the coming years. The project advanced the understanding in the field of radio spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency as well as QoE for video applications for emerging wireless networks with densely deployed underlay devices, which are expected to play a key role in the modem society to meet the future wireless capacity explosion and energy consumption escalation.

During the four years of the project, the project team investigated two of the most challenging issues of emerging communication network design in next generation wireless network with densely deployed underlay devices, and studied spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency aspects and their interactions in with QoE. The project team proposed novel approaches of comprehensive study on WN-DDUD at two levels: 1) Energy efficient radio resource access and its tradeoff with spectrum efficiency in a WNDDUD & 2) QoE aware spectrum and energy efficient radio resource access for video applications in WN-DDUD. In the first level, the project team investigated energy efficiency in an orthogonal mode based WN-DDUD, as well as energy efficiency in a non-orthogonal mode based WN-DDUD, and then developed optimal power allocation methods to maximize average energy efficiency in WN-DDUD. In the second level, the project team further studied QoS-aware SE and EE for video applications in a WN-DDUD. The project team used video peak-signal-noise-ratio (PSNR) to characterize video QoE, based on which QoE-aware SE (QSE) and QoE-aware EE (QEE) are defined. Based on that, the project team investigated the system level QSE and QEE in a WN-DDUD by jointly optimizing radio resource allocation, power control and device association schemes. More specifically, various research activities were conducted:

-   Contention-based distributed medium access control for underlay devices in a WN-DDUD

-   Non-contention based distributed resource and power allocation for WN-DDUD

-   Energy efficiency in an orthogonal mode based WN-DDUD

-   Energy efficiency in a non-orthogonal mode based WN-DDUD

-   Optimal power allocation methods to maximize average energy efficiency in WN-DDUD

-   QSE and QEE based video delivery over a WN-DDUD

-   QEE-QSE tradeoff study in a WN-DDUD

Computer simulations were developed to evaluate the performance and tradeoffs and validate the theoretical results for spectrum and energy efficient radio resource access in WN-DDUD. As part of the comprehensive study, theoretical results to achieve optimal performance for spectrum and energy efficient radio resource access in WN-DDUD, as well as practical engineering design rules and guidelines for implementation and deployment of spectrum and energy efficient radio resource access in WN-DDUD, were obtained in the series of studies above. The research activities of this project have significantly revolutionized the field of spectrum and energy efficient radio resource access in next generation wireless networks, and have a significant impact on design of spectrum and energy efficient radio resource access in WN-DDUD.
